SPEAKER: LONDON

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: PREFACE

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: If I have turned aside from Euripides for a moment and attempted a

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: translation of the great stage masterpiece of Sophocles, my excuse must

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: be the fascination of this play, which has thrown its spell on me as on

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: many other translators. Yet I may plead also that as a rule every

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: diligent student of these great works can add something to the

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: discoveries of his predecessors, and I think I have been able to bring

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: out a few new points in the old and much-studied _Oedipus_, chiefly

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: points connected with the dramatic technique and the religious

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: atmosphere.

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: Mythologists tell us that Oedipus was originally a daemon haunting Mount

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: Kithairon, and Jocasta a form of that Earth-Mother who, as Aeschylus

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: puts it, "bringeth all things to being, and when she hath reared them

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: receiveth again their seed into her body" (_Choephori_, 127: cf.

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: Crusius, _Beitraege z. Gr. Myth_, 21). That stage of the story lies very

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: far behind the consciousness of Sophocles. But there does cling about

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: both his hero and his heroine a great deal of very primitive atmosphere.

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: There are traces in Oedipus of the pre-hellenic Medicine King, the

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: _Basileus_ who is also a _Theos_, and can make rain or blue sky,

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: pestilence or fertility. This explains many things in the Priest's first

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: speech, in the attitude of the Chorus, and in Oedipus' own language

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: after the discovery. It partly explains the hostility of Apollo, who is

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: not a mere motiveless Destroyer but a true Olympian crushing his

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: Earth-born rival. And in the same way the peculiar royalty of Jocasta,

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: which makes Oedipus at times seem not the King but the Consort of the

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: Queen, brings her near to that class of consecrated queens described in

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: Dr. Frazer's _Lectures on the Kingship_, who are "honoured as no woman

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: now living on the earth."

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: The story itself, and the whole spirit in which Sophocles has treated

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: it, belong not to the fifth century but to that terrible and romantic

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: past from which the fifth century poets usually drew their material. The

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: atmosphere of brooding dread, the pollution, the curses; the "insane and

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: beastlike cruelty," as an ancient Greek commentator calls it, of

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: piercing the exposed child's feet in order to ensure its death and yet

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: avoid having actually murdered it (_Schol. Eur. Phoen._, 26); the whole

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: treatment of the parricide and incest, not as moral offences capable of

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: being rationally judged or even excused as unintentional, but as

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: monstrous and inhuman pollutions, the last limit of imaginable horror:

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: all these things take us back to dark regions of pre-classical and even

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: pre-homeric belief. We have no right to suppose that Sophocles thought

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: of the involuntary parricide and metrogamy as the people in his play do.

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: Indeed, considering the general tone of his contemporaries and friends,

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: we may safely assume that he did not. But at any rate he has allowed no

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: breath of later enlightenment to disturb the primaeval gloom of his

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: atmosphere.

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: Does this in any way make the tragedy insincere? I think not. We know

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: that people did feel and think about "pollution" in the way which

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: Sophocles represents; and if they so felt, then the tragedy was there.

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: I think these considerations explain the remarkable absence from this

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: play of any criticism of life or any definite moral judgment. I know

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: that some commentators have found in it a "humble and unquestioning

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: piety," but I cannot help suspecting that what they saw was only a

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: reflection from their own pious and unquestioning minds. Man is indeed

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: shown as a "plaything of Gods," but of Gods strangely and

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: incomprehensibly malignant, whose ways there is no attempt to explain or

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: justify. The original story, indeed, may have had one of its roots in a

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: Theban "moral tale." Aelian (_Varia Historia_, 2, 7) tells us that the

SPEAKER: LONDON
TEXT: exposure of a child was forbidden by Theban Law. The state of feeling
